author: holiman
content: Hi, sorry, just joined

author: axic3354
content:
Regarding transaction types there was this collection of proposals (and an attempt to merge them into a simple system): https://notes.ethereum.org/@axic/Hyrc1i7ED

I did not take it further (yet) to make an EIP, because focusing on rich transactions seemed like an intriguing idea.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm still mildly in favor of Rich Transactions over AA.  While I get that AA is the more complete solution, it comes with *soooo* much more complexity and risks (DoS).

author: sky.cactus
content: By having gas payment and signing outside, but otherwise allowing addresses to execute code directly (e.g., delegate call) we get rid of almost all of the complexity of AA while retaining *most* of the benefits.

author: lightclient
content: although I agree that there is more risk to AA there is much more reward, and i think the latest iteration (EIP-2938) is actually rather elegant

author: lightclient
content: my personal preference is to start with sponsored tx + wallet contracts + relayers as it is the most minimal change to achieve "rich txs"

author: sky.cactus
content: The latest iteration does mitigate the risks to some extent, I believe the complexity is still pretty high compared to rich transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the biggest win of AA is "contract pays fees", and as someone who uses a contract wallet I can say that such a feature would be nice.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, needing to have some gas money on my signer is not particularly onerous either, and certainly far from the biggest pain point I run into.

author: lightclient
content: what are your thoughts on sponsored tx + wallet contract + relayers vs. rich txs?

author: sky.cactus
content: What is "wallet contract"?

author: sky.cactus
content: My current favorite is Rich + flags + sponsorship I think.

author: lightclient
content: gnosis safe, argent, etc

author: sky.cactus
content: Where "flags" means accesslist/expiry at the moment.

author: sky.cactus
content: I very much dislike like the *current* "meta-transaction" thing people are doing.

author: sky.cactus
content: In my experience, needing ETH for gas is not the giant UX hurdle that everyone seems to think it is.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is, there are *many* other problems that users run into at a higher frequency.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe the counter-argument to that is that we just aren't seeing the users who would have this problem because they never use Ethereum in the first place.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, sponsored transactions solves that problem *better* IMO.

author: _shemnon
content: <@!211091239112671234> I think EIP-2929 should have test cases for CREATE and CREATE2 since their address warming is called out in the spec.

author: poojaranjan
content: Breakout-room Meeting 3 (summary) - https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/208#issuecomment-696215635

author: holiman
content: Yes, there are a lot of cases that should be made into tests -- I picked the low hanging ones first off - those that didn't require any calls or prestate

author: _shemnon
content: Yea, getting a cold read for another account really requires prestate.

author: _shemnon
content: Re EIP-2929, does the list of state results https://gist.github.com/holiman/8f54f24008b57d303c92f24732a14943 include the most recent Geth?
